climbs.name: Yellowjacket
climbs.fa: Al Hospers, Judy and Joe Perez

content.description: Starts by climbing a "mini-butress" about 15' high to a pointed top, where you can clip the first bolt. The base of the "mini-butress" is about 10-15 ft of high-angle dirt-and-rock scrambling, so prudence might suggest one trad piece. Climb up past another two bolts, clip the third bolt and make some balance moves on a flake.Then clip the fourth and final bolt and pull the bulge on more balance move to an easy short slab with no pro to the anchors.
content.location: Hike left along the cliff, when the Trail forks stay to the left, (right goes up to Wanderlust.) The first route you come to is Easy As Pudding Pie, Yellowjacket is the second route.

climbs.name: Wabi Sabi West
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Mike Kahn, Jeff Wilson, Sep 2010

content.description: Climb the mossy wall to a ledge with two small trees. Veer left and continue up the slab and pass a right facing flake. Up the shallow corner to less steep terrain to a tree belay.
content.location: From the main area of the Geriatric walls, keep hiking left (west) until you reach a 150' slab with a curvy beach tree close by. This route starts down left at a short dark mossy wall.

climbs.name: The Wabi Sabi Way
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Mike Kahn, Apr 2005

content.description: Climb the slab to the top and a tree belay.
content.location: From the main area of the Geriatric walls, keep hiking left (west) until you reach a 150' slab with a curvy beach tree close by. This route starts at the toe.

climbs.name: Tree Keys
climbs.fa: Judy Perez, Joe Perez, George Hurley

content.description:
Find the tree close to the cliff with a key embedded in the trunk near eye level, on the cliffside of the tree. The keyring has broken off of the key (and it is sometimes replaced) so you may need to look hard for it.  

  The route ascends a dark brown slab starting from the tree. Climb the lower slab to the blocky 4th class ledge, then climb the outside corner hanging overhead. The route touches both faces of the outside corner. A routefinding extravaganza!
content.protection: Can be done with only bolts. If 5.7 is your limit, bring a couple cams for the slightly runout section midway up the climb (it's not that runout, but some will want an extra piece of pro)
content.location: Find the tree with the key in it. About 100 yards from Cake Walk, this climb begins before you reach the big elevated  dirty ledge where Gaggle of Geese, Old Crow and High Steppin' start.

climbs.name: Toulouse
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Mike Kahn, Aug 20 1999

content.description: Climb the corner to the top.
content.location: Up and left of the Wabi Sabi slab and a hundred yards or so before Lost Canadian area. Look for a big impressive overhanging corner and scoop and a wide chimney to the left.

climbs.name: Three Brushes
climbs.fa: Chris Magness, Jessi Soroka

climbs.name: Steppin Out
climbs.fa: Chris Graham & Dave Penny

content.description:
Climb the slab left of the left facing corner to a bolt which is just to the right of a small overhang. Climb past the bolt to a diagonal trending crack/overlap that takes small cams. Continue past another bolt and head left (about 15Â’) up the gully. There is a good cam placement on the left under a boulder. Make strenuous face moves on good holds up the black wall to the center of the roof above.Follow weakness to the left. A good cam placement (#2 or #3) protects the moves out over the roof. 

Note: Though it looks tempting to escape out right to avoid the roof, the rock is of poor quality and is not to be trusted.
content.protection:
Gear: Small cams for the diagonal crack, large cams for the roof. 

  2 bolts and trad gear to a two bolt anchor with rings.
content.location:
Directions:  Humphrey's Ledge, North of Cathedral Ledge on West Side Road. Park on the road across from the Lady Blanche House. Walk into the woods and follow a trail up to the cliff. Hike left along the cliff band until you reach a right-facing corner where the trail drops down. Hike along the left of the cliff until you get to the last obvious climbs. Walk downhill about 300' to a clean slab with a line of bolts in the middle and two more bolts just right of a small right-facing corner. Continue up a small incline to a comfortable ledge with a couple of trees. The climb begins to the left of Old Crow and a dark left facing corner that is often wet.    Description: This is a nice, Variation to the finish of High Steppin. Good gear under the roof protects the final moves. After pulling the roof, step right and finish at the two bolt anchor for High Steppin and Old Crow. 

  Descent: rappel the route

climbs.name: Silent Treatment
climbs.fa: George Hurley and Al Hospers, Aug 6 2013

content.description: Climb the face, passing two bolts, to a 2 bolt anchor (shared with Three Brushes).
content.location: At the far left of the main area, just left of Three Brushes. Look for "clean" face between all the moss.

climbs.name: Rumble in the Jungle
climbs.fa: George Hurley and David Giampitro, Aug 9 2009 (p1-2),  George Hurley and Sara Reeder Sep 21, 2009 (p3)

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb the left facing corner with a birch tree. Continue up the arete to a ledge and a juniper bush (5.8, 60').

Pitch 2: Climb easy cracks and continue easy dirty slab until headwall (5.5, 40').

Pitch 3: Start on rock pillar at left end side of ledge. Climb through four bolts to a 2 bolt anchor (5.10a, 60').
content.location: A little right of Tree Keys. Look for a large left facing corner.

climbs.name: Retread
climbs.fa: George Hurley, David Giampietro, Mike Kahn, Aug 2014

content.description:
Nice route on the far right. Climb slabby terrain passing a bolt to a ledge with a tree. Optionally sling the tree. Then continue the slab passing another bolt to head wall. Pass another two bolts to a ledge with a 2 bolt anchor. It's a little easier going right of the bolts and more interesting left of them. You can complement with some gear, but should be fine without if you are comfortable at the grade.

 Descent: 60 meter rope barely get you down to the start
content.location: The farthest route to the right. Look for a tree on a ledge 20 feet up with a bolt little before that.

climbs.name: Relapped
climbs.fa: Mike Kahn and George Hurley, Sep 2010

content.description: Climb the steep slab passing four bolts to lower angle terrain and overlap.. Continue up using bolt and then pass another bolt. Continue short easier slab to a second overlap and to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Continue past the main Geriatric area to "Cornered". There is a big fallen pine tree at the base. Scramble (or climb) up the dirty gully to the right to a ledge at the base of the steep slab.

climbs.name: Put My Foot Where?
climbs.fa: Joe Perez, Al Hospers, Judy Perez

content.description: Fun slightly over hanging route with a thin crux bulge, Start on big holds heading slightly left past 4 bolts to a nice rest before the crux. Clip the final bolt and crimp yourself over the bulge.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two ringed anchor
content.location: This climb starts in a scoop just right of the pillar on Yellowjacket.

climbs.name: Old Dogs
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Mike Kahn, Aug 20 1999

content.description: Climb small inside corners to a ledge and continue up the face to the top using a finger crack and other holds.
content.location: Around 30' right of Lost Canadian and just left of Kitty Litter Pillar that you can identify by the crumbly looking buttress and black streak higher up.

climbs.name: Old Crow
climbs.fa: Al Hospers

content.description: Start at the tree that is wedged against the cliff, and climb up the blocky slab to the horizontal flakes. Gain the headwall and make balance moves to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus small cams and nuts
content.location:
Immediately right of High Steppin` 

  As you walk to the end of the flat, elevated ledge that houses the climbs Gaggle Of Geese, It's Not What It Seems, and Anniversary, the trail starts uphill past a tree that is growing directly against the cliff.  

  That's where you want to be.

climbs.name: New Blood
climbs.fa: Jonathan Garlough & Chris Magness

content.description:
New Blood is the project formerly known as Ain't Nothing in the Handren guide.  

  This route climbs the arete just left of Around the Corner.  

  Climb the unprotected 5.8 slab to a horizontal/crack with good gear. Pull the overlap and place a pink tricam in a slot in the flake. Make the crux moves up the thin seam and arete past two bolts. Finish at a bolt anchor on the ledge. 

  The start is often wet, but can be avoided by climbing the slab to the left past to bolts to a horizontal. Traverse right to the crack.
content.protection: cams, pink tricam, bolts, bolt anchor
content.location: Left of Around the Corner

climbs.name: Lost Canadian
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Maury McKinney, May 8 1999

content.description: Climb the chimney like area between the pillar and main wall and continue up the corner to the top.
content.location: Last route in the Geraitric Wall area and a little bit of a hike. Find a big right facing corner with a big pillar/block forming a chimney.

climbs.name: Lost and Found
climbs.fa: Chris Graham & Bob Ahearn

content.description: Bouldery moves up to the first bolt then follow a quartzite dyke to a large flake (#2 Camalot). Make tricky moves over the next bulge to a rest at mid height. Continue trending right on a steep ramp to the crux moves up and over the final headwall. Small cams are helpful after pulling over the final bulge. Finish up the slab on nice holds to a two bolt anchor. 90'
content.protection: Gear: draws, a (#2 or #3) Camelot, assorted small cams for the finish. 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Directions:  Hike left along the cliff band until you reach a right-facing corner and buttress where the trail drops down. Walk downhill past a small slab (As Easy as Instant Pudding Pie) and look for an obvious blocky buttress. The climb starts 15' left of put my foot where? 

  Rap from the anchor.

climbs.name: The Life of Riley
climbs.fa: Al Hospers, Judy Perez, Joe Perez, Apr 15 2010

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb slab to right facing overlap. Pass it on the right and clip a bolt. Continue over the headwall and corner to tree ledge (5.9, 50').

Pitch 2: Cimb toe of rock. Veer left and back right and over a small roof. Pass a small slab and over a small nose to a tree belay. (5.6, 60').
content.location: Towards the left end of the main area, just before Three Brushes. There is a small uphill section with a fixed knotted rope.

climbs.name: Kitty Litter Pillar
climbs.fa: Chris Graham & Bob Ahearn

content.description: Â•	Pitch 1: Climb easily but cautiously at the start of a steep buttress (good gear placements can be found behind the flakes to the left). continue up to the top of the buttress (either slinging the pillar or opting for a large cam placement on the right) to the start of a beautiful and obvious black streak with impeccable face climbing. One bolt protects the crux moves near the top!
content.protection: Gear:Â 1 bolt near the top, standard rack with several small cams (#00 TCU up to a size 3.5). don't leave the Tri-cams at home as there are several opportunities to place them along the way. One bolt at 3/4 height protects the crux moves to a nice horizontal to a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
Directions:Â  To find this route, walk west along the stream bed, which comes from the cirque just south of Humphrey's Ledge. When you are about 100 yards from the West Side Road the stream valley is fairly flat. When it starts to get steeper, turn right (north) up a short talus slope. Find an eight-foot high corner with a 30Ã­ pillar to its left. There is also a newly established path that leads past Wabi Sabi Way and along the bottom of the cliff. The path is loose and gravelly and care should be taken if you choose this route. 

  Description: located 30' right of Lost Canadian, locate a "somewhat" crumbly buttress with beautiful black streak above. Despite the relatively loose looking quality of the start, the upper portion of the climb is not to be missed and offers 35Â’ of some of the best steep face climbing that HumphreyÂ’s has to offer. 

  Descent:Â rappel the route with 1 rope.Â

climbs.name: It's Not What It Seems
climbs.fa: Joe Perez, Al Hospers, Judy Perez and Jeff Lea

content.description: Starts on the right side of the ledge. climb up past 2 bolts on easy slab to a horizontal. climb past 3 bolts to a rest ledge before the crux.Clip the bolt and grab a flake by your stomach and get high feet and make a reach for a good right hand sloper. Its not as far as it looks. Gain the ledge and then its easy 5.4 climbing to the top.
content.location: This is the sport route on the right of the raised ledge.

climbs.name: Incontinent Dog
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description: Climb wall following bolts and through a short slab. Continue to headwall. Surmount it with some hard moves to a slab and 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 7 bolts and #1/#2 cam after last boltÂ
content.location: Pass "Yellowjacket" pillar and "Lost and Found", little left of a tree.

climbs.name: High Steppin`
climbs.fa: Al Hospers, Judy and Joe Perez

content.description: Slabby face left of a left-facing corner, past a tree-ledge to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
200 yards past Cake Walk, at a large, dirty ledge with two trees on it. To get there, walk down from Cake Walk, pass the right-end climbs (Pudding Pie, Yellow Jacket) and walk along the long, flat, elevated ledge uphill from Tree Keys.  

  At the end of this elevated ledge, the trail scrambles up onto a dirty tree ledge where High Steppin and Old Crow start.

climbs.name: Gaggle of Geese
climbs.fa: The Perez's

content.description:
A nice and closely bolted moderate sport climb. Start on the elevated ledge, clip the low first bolt from the ground, and climb a few thin moves to get up the slab, heading toward a small roof up and left. Continue past the roof on the right or left (I went right, but left looked reasonable also), and on to easier ground to a 2 bolt anchor up and left. 

  It helps to tram in while cleaning, as it is mostly left-trending.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt rap anchor.
content.location: Locate the super low bolt on an elevated ledge in the middle section of the Geriatric wall. Follow the bolts to the top!

climbs.name: Daddy's Got New Shoes
climbs.fa: Al Hospers, Joe Perez, Judy Perez, Sep 10 2011

content.description: Climb the mossy start for 30' and continue over a "cleaner" face to a bolt. Clip it and climb through the overlaps to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: At the left end of the main area, a little after Three Brushes. Find a mossy start with some overlaps higher up.

climbs.name: Cornered
climbs.fa: George Hurley, Mike Kahn, Jun 2010

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb the corner-crack passing some clocks at the top before reaching a ledge and belay tree (50').

Pitch 2: Continue up dirty slab, then a shallow right facing corner and easier slab to a large crack below an overlap (60'). (Can easily be combined but you won't be able to see each other)

 Descent: 30m rappel from tree
content.location: Walk up/left (west) from Three Brushes and the main Geriatric wall area and not much after at the height of land you will see a dirty gully with a fallen pine tree. Above is a big right facing corner with a wide crack along the face / inside corner.

climbs.name: Cold Feet
climbs.fa: Chris Magness, Jamie Schaaf, 8/10

content.description:
A gear protected variation to Anniversary.   

  Climb the flake just left of Anniversary, pull the roof and join Anniversary at it's last bolt. 

  Easier 5.10 if you pull the roof left trending, harder 5.10 if you pull it straight on. 

  The crux gear is extremely marginal.  Could improve with traffic.
content.protection: small stuff. look for a hidden small/medium sized cam below the seam at the overlap.
content.location: left side.

climbs.name: The Badlands
climbs.fa: George Hurley and Al Hospers, Sep 17 2013

content.description: Climb the steppy face up to the headwall. Pass it on the right side and back left. Continue up via some maples to the top and belay tree.
content.location: 15' right of Tree Key's. Looks for face with steps/ledges.

climbs.name: Autumn Tears (pitch 2)
climbs.fa: George Hurley, David Giampietro and Ed Matt, Nov 6 2013.

content.description:
Climb straight up the head wall passing two bolts. Continue using some gear to rope anchor at tree.

Descent: 60m should reach the bottom

 (Wrote up as separate route as the first pitch is a nice 5.6 sport that should not be overlooked. The second pitch was added a couple of weeks later.)
content.location: Second pitch of Autumn Tears, just right of the anchors.

climbs.name: Autumn Tears
climbs.fa: David Giampietro and Ed Matt Oct 24, 2013

content.description:
Climb up the face to first bolt, optionally placing a nut on the way. It's easier going on the right and then traverse left to the first bolt. Then passing two more bolts straight up. Now the terrain gets easier and more slabby but without any more protection until the head wall. A 2 bolt anchor is set rather high so an extra move or two is requires to reach it.

 Second pitch is 5.9 trad and described separately.
content.location: Just right of Yellowjacket, which you identify by the broken pillar.

climbs.name: As Easy as Instant Pudding Pie (pitch 2)
climbs.fa: George Hurley and David Giampietro, Nov 16 2013

content.description:
Climb corner/crack on gear and fun moves. Then continue up the flatiron/buttress on the left side, to ledge. This part is shared with ""Let Them Eat Cake". Stop at ledge and belay at 2 bolt anchor (of "Retread") or continue up until tree anchor of "Cakewalk".

Direct variation: Â From anchor it goes at 5.10 with an enjoyable upper section. There are a couple bolt heads at the crux (without hangers).

Descent: From 2-bolt anchor, 60m rope just reaches bottom.

 (Wrote up as separate route as the first pitch is a nice easy 5.4 sport. The second pitch was added a few years later.)
content.location: Second pitch to As Easy as Instant Pudding Pie. Corner/crack just left of anchor.

climbs.name: As Easy as Instant Pudding Pie
climbs.fa: Judy and Joe Perez

content.description: Climb up past 3 bolts to a 2 bolt ring anchors, the name says it all.
content.location: Walk left along the cliff when the trail forks stay to the left (right brings you up to Wanderlust & Cakewalk.) "Easy" is the second bolted route you'll come to, just to the right of a tree at the base.

climbs.name: Around the Corner
climbs.fa: July 31,2011 - Dave Penny, Chris Graham, Bob Ahearn

content.description:
The route consists of a slab to a nicely featured face and then finishes up a steep corner. Dave Penny discovered the route when he bailed right around a corner from a 5.12 project. Under heavy lichen he found nicely featured rock, which he used to climb up and retrieve his top rope anchor. 

      Pitch 1: Step up on nice rock to clip the first bolt. Step onto the ledge and lay the crack back to the right (protected by cams). When the crack ends, step left onto the face with nicely featured rock protected by bolts. Surmount the face onto a ledge. Follow the corner up past three bolts ( crux) to join the last bolt and anchor on Tree Keys.
content.protection: 8 bolts, 1 or 2 cams, 1 optional cam before exit, or just pull on thru. Cams are small to mid
content.location: Hike left along the cliff past Robinson Crusoe. As the trail goes uphill to Wanderlust take a left on a separate trail. The first route you come to is Easy As Pudding Pie. Continue along the cliff gradually uphill and look for a tree close to the cliff with keys embedded in the trunk near eye level. This is Tree Keys. Around the Corner starts 15 ft left of Tree Keys, directly in front of the beech tree.

climbs.name: Anniversary
climbs.fa: Al Hospers, Judy and Joe Perez

content.description: Start on the left side of the ledge by a good size flake. Climb the slab to the right of the flake past two bolts to just under a nose. Climb out right of the nose untill your feet are even with the bottom of the nose then clip a bolt then step out onto it. Climb up esay slab to the top. You can all so pull strait onto the nose at a little bit of a harder grade. The route says trad in the guide book but you can do it as sport if you run it out a bit.
content.location: The route starts on the left side of the raised ledge.

content.description:
The Geriatric Wall has mostly one pitch routes on it. Not a bad place to go if you want to knock out like 8 to 10 pitches of moderate climbing in one day. Do not go when it hot out because the swamp makes this place unbelievably muggy....I found out the hard way. 

  [ NOTE: There's a "Quick Topo" of the area posted on the main Humphrey's page. R.Hall ]
